Applications of CFD in distillation, FCC and delayed coking technologies at Cenpes downstream basic engineering Aplicações da fluidodinâmica computacional (CFD) nas tecnologias de destilação, FCC e coqueamento retardado na engenharia básica de abastecimento do Cenpes Aplicaciones de la fluidodinámica computacional (CFD) en las tecnologias del destilación, FCC y coquización retardada en la ingeniería básica de refinamiento del Cenpes André Gonçalves Oliveira J Guilherme Pimentel da Silva Karolline Ropelato Washington Geraldelli Abstract The Oil and Gas Industry has several multiphase flow applications and the CFD technique is capable of bringing more accurate solutions for complex flow problems. Some cases require a deep understanding of the phenomena, for example, inter-phase heat and mass transfer and gas-particle interaction. Basic Engineering Process Teams (Coking, Distillation and FCC) have been using the CFD technique for more than seven years. The CFD cases played an important role in the improvement of these technologies. Some of them are discussed here: evaluation of inlet feed device, heat and mass transfer in empty sections, collector pans, cyclone dust hopper influence on the vortex core, coke drum effluent quench, inlet design and baffles in coke fractionators. keywords: ■ CFD ■ coking ■ quench ■ gas-solid ■ multiphase flow ■ separation ■ cyclone ■ fractionator Resumo A Indústria de Petróleo e Gás tem várias aplicações de escoamentos multifásicos e a técnica de CFD é capaz de trazer soluções mais precisas para os problemas de fluxos complexos. Alguns casos requerem uma profunda compreensão dos fenômenos, como por exemplo, a transferência de calor e de massa e a interação gás-sólido. As equipes de processo da engenharia básica de refino (coqueamento retardado, destilação e FCC) utilizam a técnica de CFD há mais de sete anos. Os casos de CFD tiveram um papel importante no desenvolvimento destas tecnologias. Alguns deles são discutidos aqui: a avaliação de bocais de carga, a transferência de calor e massa em seções de vazios, panelas coletores, a influência do dust hopper ciclone no vortex core, o resfriamento (quench) do efluente do tambor de coqueamento, e a entrada de carga e chicanas em fracionadoras da unidade de coqueamento retardado. palavras-chave: ■ CFD ■ coqueamento ■ quench ■ gás-sólido ■ escoamento multifásico ■ separação ■ ciclone ■ fracionadora. Resumen La industria del Petróleo y Gas tiene varias aplicaciones de flujos multifásicos y la técnica del CFD es capaz de aportar soluciones más precisas para los problemas de flujos complejos. Algunos casos requieren una profunda comprensión de los fenómenos, por ejemplo, la transferencia de calor y masa y la interacción gas-sólido. Los grupos de proceso de la ingeniería básica (coquización retardada, destilación y FCC) usan la técnica de CFD a más de siete anos. Los casos del CFD tuvieron un papel importante en el desarrollo de estas tecnologias. Algunos de ellos se discuten aquí: la evaluación de la boca de la alimentación, la transferencia de calor y masa en los sectores con aspersores, los colectores, la influencia del dust hopper de los ciclones en el vortex core, resfriamiento (quench) de los vapores de la cabeza del tambor del coque, y la boca de la alimentación y los deflectores en las fraccionadoras de coque. palabras-clave: ■ CFD ■ coquización ■ quench ■ gas-sólido ■ flujo multifásico ■ separación ■ ciclón ■ fraccionadoras. Introduction Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) is a powerful tool applied by process engineers in design, investigation and the development of a deep industrial knowledge basis. It is capable of bringing more accurate solutions for complex flow problems and is especially useful for cases with complex geometries and under conditions in which measurement is difficult. The Basic Engineering sector at Cenpes has been using this technique for some years. The Basic Engineering Process Teams focused on Distillation, Delayed Coking and FCC technologies have studied several cases, which have played an important role in the improvement of these technologies. Some of them are presented here: Feed Nozzles The performance of a vacuum tower is greatly influenced by the flow pattern within the feed region. Therefore, the proper fluid dynamic design of feed devices is paramount to enhance the column's performance, (Palatino etal., 2003). The original geometry exposed some performance issues in terms of vapor distribution and liquid entrainment. A CFD study was carried out to improve the geometry and the results showed excellent performance in terms of vapor distribution and liquid entrainment. The differences between the evaluated geometries are shown in figure 1. The geometry proposed by Koch Glitsch was evaluated as an alternative to avoid vapor peaks and liquid drag to upper sections. Empty Section Studies A multiphase model was applied to the vacuum tower, to model the vapor-liquid flow. (Ropelato et al., 2009). Characteristic time scales are used to classify and understand the dominant mechanisms in gas-liquid suspensions, (Elgobashi et al., 1994; Peirano et al., 1998). This methodology is widespread and therefore can be applied to any turbulent gas-liquid or Figure 1 - Original geometry and new proposal. | Figura 1 - Geometria original e a nova proposta. | Figura 1 - Geometria original y la nueva propuesta. gas-solid flow. A discussion on the model's validity is given, as well as an application to distillation vacuum towers. The Stokes in Kolmogorov scale is a very important parameter in liquid-vapor flows. If the Stokes number approaches zero, the droplets response time is lower than the characteristic time associated with the flow field. Thus the droplets will have enough time to respond to the changes in the flow field. In other words, droplets and vapor will be flowing at very similar velocities. If the opposite behavior occurs the droplets' velocity is unaffected by the vapor phase. The Stokes number in the vacuum tower is shown in figure 2 and those regions with the Stokes number close to one are in risk of coalescence. The studied region did not show a strong risk of this phenomenon occurring. There are no assumptions in the model with this regard. Problems with large coalescence regions should be addressed with a more suitable model. Collector Pans The fluid flow uniformity characterizes the performance of liquid distributors (Heggemann etal., 2007). Collector pans determine the liquid feed flow to the distributors as they are located in the previous section of the tower. The formation of stagnation zones must be avoided in the columns, because the mass transfer processes only occurs in regions effectively wetted, so it is vital to have a homogeneous liquid distribution. Despite the simplicity of this modeling, it has proved useful to identify the collector pan behavior. In particular, the CFD analysis characterized the liquid distribution and predicted the chimney arrangement influence and sump draw-off rates. The results indicated the need for an engineering analy sis of the column internals selection, taking into account the general operating conditions, especially for packed columns. The optimum performance and desired operating ranges can only be achieved when the tower packing/internals are precisely designed and carefully selected for individual cases. Cyclone Dust Hopper Influence on the Vortex Core Boundary conditions effects in cyclone simulation using CFD were studied applying a three-dimensional unstructured mesh and using a Reynolds Stress Model for turbulence modeling. Two of the most important variables in a cyclone operation were taken into consideration: the pressure drop and the velocity field (tangential and axial velocity). Different sets of geometries, meshes and operational conditions of two different cyclones were tested based on experimental data from the literature. There are many different types of cyclone configurations, but the reverse-flow cyclone with a tangential inlet is the most common. Dirgo et al. (1985) and Qian et al. (2009) cyclone geometries were used in this study. Dirgo etal. (1985) tested five air flows to evaluate the pressure drop (5, 10, 15, 20, 25m/s). It is important to stress that, for low cyclone inlet velocities, results as good as 0.07% of deviation were obtained. For both tetrahedral and hexahedral meshes shown in figure 4, with or without a hopper, the results show good agreement with experimental data. Furthermore, at higher velocities, around 20m/s, the hexahedral mesh shows better results. This may be due to the less dissipative nature of this kind of mesh element. Notable in all cases (fig.5), the hopper significantly modifies the cyclone flow field, showing its importance in the simulation. When comparing similar cases between a he-xahedral or tetrahedral mesh, the results show that the latter tends to be more dissipative than the former, resulting in a poorer shaped core. Considering the experimental apparatus used in Dirgo et al. (1983), the influence of a small hopper was also analysed and verified. Actually, the combination of the hopper presence and a hexahedral mesh gave the best match with the experimental results. The complete study is presented by Ropelato etal. Coke Drum Effluent Quench The CFD technique was applied to study the best point to inject the gas oil to quench the reactions at the coke drum outlet aiming to avoid coke formation in the transfer line from the coke drum to the fractionator. The gas oil injection in the vapor line that connects the coke drum to the fractionator controls the temperature to stop the coking reactions. Along with many other factors, this temperature depends on the feedstock. There is a relationship between the stock characterization factor and the cracking temperature. The higher the characterization factor, i.e. more paraffinic, the lower the temperature at which incipient cracking begins and there is a critical decomposition zone for each feedstock (Rose, 1971). The main results are shown in figure 6. The top side and uniform gas oil inlet is shown in figure 6a (case 1), where the results indicate the high speed values of effluent stream drags the quench stream towards the wall, allowing the effluent to find a larger free area. A similar phenomenon may be observed in figure 6a (case 2). Note the best mixing was achieved when the case 3 layout was used, by means of two sprays with a cone angle of 68°. All free area was avoided in this last case. Complete study details can be found in Barros et al. (2008). The CFD results and experimental information were used to validate the numerical achievements. The first transfer line vertical section is shown in figure 6b just after the top flange of the coke drum. This photo was taken during a delayed coking unit shut down, which has the same configuration as case 3, as shown in figure 6a. Note an expressive amount of coke deposited inside the transfer line, which could be related to an inadequate spray pressure drop. The basic liquid in let condition is represented in figure 7 with both case studies considering the upper spray sections are the same. The only difference is in the second spray section (lower spray section) with respect to the rotation condition. The first has 30 degrees of rotation in relation to the fixed upper section and the other has 45 degrees of rotation. Coke Fractionator - Feed Inlet Design and Baffles Until recently, licensors have designed coker fractionators with only one inlet feed nozzle. However, in new coker designs, especially those with four coke drums, a different design has been introduced to the transfer line from the coke drum to the fractionator and, as a result, two inlet feed nozzles are being used. Using only one inlet feed device generates high vertical velocities that can be observed near the wall opposite the inlet nozzle, as well as a large flow recirculation in the flash and washing zones, causing an efficiency reduction on the heat and Figure 8 - Liquid volume fraction for a second level rotated 30 degrees. Figura 8 - Fração de volume de líquido para um segundo nível girado em 30 graus. Figura 8 - Fracción del volumen de líquido en un segundo plano girado en 30 grados. mass transfer between liquid and vapor phases. Vapor maldistribution in this section must be avoided as it increases the probability of undesirable coke formation. Process conditions are also key factors to determine the most efficient inlet configuration for a particular coker fractionator. The CFD study analyzed the flow for one, two and three inlet feed devices. The number of inlet feed device affects the velocity profile as shown in figure 9. The more usual single inlet feed device gives a poor vapor distribution as can be seen in figure 9 and the vapor forms a layer near the wall up to the top level. Even though there is some recirculation, the two inlet device promotes good vapor distribution with uniform gas velocity up to the top of the fractionator. The three inlet design does not perform as well as two inlets. An evaluation of the coker fractionator tower baffles design is shown in figure 10: the optimization of the first baffle height (above vapor inlet), the number of gas passes through baffles and the uniformity of the vapor flow after the last baffle were all analyzed. The CFD results indicate that changes in the first baffle height are required to reduce the total equipment height. This design modification was combined with the previous study that indicated the optimum number of device inlets. The analysis showed the advantage of changing the number of inlet feed devices of the coker fractionator tower, using two or three inlets rather than one. The CFD results indicated that under normal operational conditions, the two inlets feed device was the best configuration of those evaluated. (Rope-lato et al., 2007). The results show good agreement with experimental data and have proven to be an important tool for design and investigation regarding complex flow phenomena. The literature presents many CFD cases, but most of them don't represent the industrial reality due to a lack of understanding of the process or CFD knowledge. The thorough comprehension of the phenomena and CFD knowledge are important factors for the success of a CFD analysis. After several years applying CFD technique, the Basic Engineering Process Teams have more confidence and experience. FCC, Distillation and Delayed Coking technologies still offer many challenges. Therefore, new studies are being carried out. ■ ■ ■ Referências Bibliográficas ■ COSTA BARROS, F C.; AMARAL, T. P; ROPELATO, K. A CFD investigation in delayed coking units. Autores André Gonçalves Oliveira Centro de Pesquisas da Petrobras (Cenpes) Gerência de Coque e Processos de Separação e-mail: aoliveira@petrobras.com.br Guilherme Pimentel Centro de Pesquisas da Petrobras (Cenpes) Gerência de Coque e Processos de Separação e-mail: guilhermepimentel@petro-bras.com.br André Gonçalves Oliveira graduou-se em Engenharia Química pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), em 2003. Obteve pós-graduação em Engenharia de Processamento de Petróleo pela Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), em 2006. Atuou, entre 2004 e 2005 como engenheiro de software na ESSS tendo sido responsável por estudos de Fluidodinâmica Computacional aplicados a tecnologias de Coqueamento Retardado e Destilação no Cenpes. Após a pós-graduação retornou ao Cenpes como engenheiro de Processamento, aonde atua desde então em Projeto Básico de Unidades de Coqueamento Retardado, tais como Refinaria do Nordeste (Rnest) e Complexo Petroquímico do Rio de Janeiro (Comperj). Atua na área de Pesquisa & Desenvolvimento na área de reações de craqueamento térmico, na caracterização de resíduos de petróleo, no estudo de asfal-tenos e em Fluidodinâmica Computacional à tecnologia de conversão térmica, em conjunto com a Universidade de Tulsa. Também trabalha com Simulação Dinâmica de Processos. Guilherme Pimentel graduou-se em Engenharia Química pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), em 2006, onde também cursou sua especialização em Refino de Petróleo, no Programa de Recursos Humanos da ANP no mesmo ano. Em 2008 obteve pós-graduação em Engenharia de Processamento de Petróleo pela Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), ao final do curso de formação de engenheiros de processamento da Petrobras. Desde 2008 trabalha no Cenpes, onde atua em Projetos Básicos de Unidades de Coqueamento Retardado e também em Pesquisa & Desenvolvimento com foco na área de craqueamento térmico e em sistemas multifásicos. Além disso, realiza o acompanhamento de atividades envolvendo a técnica de Fluidodi-nâmica Computacional (CFD), como projetos de pesquisa em conjunto com a Universidade de Tulsa sobre a tecnologia de Coqueamento Retardado e a Rede Temática de CFD do Refino, em que o Cenpes financia linhas de pesquisa com a técnica de CFD em universidades brasileiras. Obteve o título de Mestre pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (Unicamp) em 2004, na área de Engenharia de Processos do curso de Engenharia Química, onde também obteve o título de Doutora em Engenharia Química em 2008. Desde a época da graduação vem desenvolvendo trabalhos na área de Fluidodinâmica Computacional (CFD), onde tem atuado nas mais diversas tecnologias de refino, tais como os processos de destilação, coqueamento retardado e FCC. Co-orienta projetos de conclusão de curso e dissertações de mestrado na área, tendo escrito artigos técnicos para revistas científicas e congressos nacionais e internacionais. É responsável pelas atividades de CFD desenvolvidas na engenharia básica do Cenpes. Washington Geraldelli graduou-se em Engenharia Química pela Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro (UFRJ), em julho de 1982. Desde então, até fevereiro de 1985, trabalhou no Grupo Ultra (Bononia), onde exerceu as funções de trainee, coordenador de Turno, gerente de Engenharia Básica e gerente de Produção. Em março de 1985 ingressou na Petrobras para fazer o curso de Engenharia de Processamento de Petróleo, concluindo a especialização em abril de 1986. Participou de diversos projetos básicos como: de Unidades de Destilação Atmosférica e Vácuo, Baterias de Pré-aquecimen-to e Unidades de Coqueamento Retardado. Obteve os graus de MSc in Process Integration (1996) e PhD in Chemical Engineering (2001), ambos pela University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (Umist). De novembro de 2003 a agosto de 2007 atuou como consultor técnico na área de Otimização Energética na Engenharia Básica do Cenpes. Desde setembro de 2007 está atuando como gerente de Engenharia Básica de Coque e Processos de Separação.
